item.title: Inaugural 'Black in X' Weeks Foster Inclusivity and Empowerment in STEM
item.description: Discover how Black in STEM events defined 2020, and how science educators can harness the spirit of inclusiveness in the classroom.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: Japan’s Hayabusa2 returns asteroid sample to Earth in “perfect condition”
item.description: The sample, which is the second-ever to be successfully taken from a space rock and ferried back to Earth, could teach us about the origins of life.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Tongass National Forest is 'America's Last Climate Sanctuary'
item.description: Opening up the Tongass National Forest to additional logging and development could have serious implications for both the environment and the Alaska Native communities that depend on it.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: 3D models help preserve landmarks like Notre Dame
item.description: Laser-scanning technology can create exceptionally detailed 3D models of cultural sites, bringing them to life online—and helping experts restore them if disaster strikes.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: A third Covid-19 vaccine is effective and cheap. What happens next?
item.description: The Pfizer, Moderna, and AstraZeneca vaccines are at least 90% effective, according to clinical trials. Here’s who may get vaccinated first.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Bring the Science of Taste into the Classroom with NOVA Resources
item.description: Use these NOVA resources to introduce students to neuroscience, chemistry, and biology concepts that explain the science behind flavor, and how smell, sight, and sound can influence the experience.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: Pfizer and Moderna Covid vaccines 95% effective in clinical trials
item.description: Both vaccines performed excellently in clinical trials. What comes next?
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Toxic synthetic 'forever chemicals' are in our water and on our plates
item.description: What makes PFAS chemicals extremely useful—and extremely hard to get rid of—are the bonds between carbon and fluorine atoms that are almost impossible to break.
item.dc:creator: Shantal Riley

item.title: The 21st Century Threat to Wildlife is "Cyberpoaching"
item.description: The growth and accessibility of the internet has transformed the illegal wildlife trade.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: Apply to Join the NOVA Science Studio
item.description: This fall, we are excited to take the NOVA Science Studio to the national stage with a virtual launch of our program that will engage students across the country.
item.dc:creator: Tenijah Hamilton

item.title: Armenia reckons with climate change and its Soviet past through reforestation
item.description: A four-year fuel blockade in the 1990s threatened the tiny country’s forests. Ever since, it’s been replanting its trees—a task that’s more complicated than expected.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: NASA’s OSIRIS-REx spacecraft will stow asteroid Bennu sample early
item.description: OSIRIS-REx scooped up so much rock, dust, and debris from Bennu that its sampling container became jammed, causing asteroid bits to leak into outer space. Now, the mission team is reassessing its sample stowing plans.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: In a swirl of rocks and dust, OSIRIS-REx probe touches an asteroid
item.description: Despite concerns that the surface of Bennu might be too rocky, the probe’s touchdown produced a dramatic shower of debris, opening the way for future insights into the mysteries of our solar system.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Where Science and Social Justice Meet
item.description: Join NOVA Education for three virtual events dedicated to the intersection of STEM education and social justice.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: NASA probe will attempt to grab a piece of an asteroid on Tuesday
item.description: OSIRIS-REx will have just three chances to touch down and snag a sample of the asteroid Bennu as it zooms through space some 204 million miles from Earth.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Interview: National Geographic marine life photographer Cristina Mittermeier
item.description: In honor of Hispanic Heritage Month, world-renowned photographer Cristina Mittermeier explains her philosophy behind conservation photography, mentorship, and the increased diversity she would like to see within the environmental movement.
item.dc:creator: Kara Norton

item.title: The secret to peace between elephants and farmers in Mozambique? Bees
item.description: Scientists use animals’ “landscapes of fear” to set limits and reestablish balance in Gorongosa National Park, where top predators were wiped out.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: A calligrapher writes with light to keep tradition alive
item.description: Equipped with a light and a camera, Karim Jabbari hopes his work can serve as a link between conservative traditional calligraphy and our augmented reality.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Search for Exoplanets with the NOVA Exoplanet Lab
item.description: You've been selected to be the lead scientist for the NOVA Space Center’s Galactic Resettlement team, with the job of finding suitable exoplanets for displaced aliens desperately seeking new homes. Are you up to the challenge?

item.title: The evolving, unexpected power of the emoji
item.description: We use emoji in texts and other messaging to set a tone, maintain relationships, and show solidarity. But are they also changing the way we think?
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Finding My Voice
item.description: Biomedical engineer, Khari Johnson, explains how underrepresentation in STEM fields is not due to lack of interest, aptitude or talent, but instead due to a number of systemic barriers.
item.dc:creator: Khari Johnson

item.title: Eight smart things slime molds can do without a brain
item.description: From remembering where they’ve been to recreating the Tokyo rail network, these “slimy aliens” are capable of way more than we give them credit for.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: An Indigenous bioethicist on CRISPR and decolonizing DNA
item.description: Gene-editing technology is progressing faster than our ethical conversations about how we should use it. Krystal Tsosie thinks that’s a problem.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Chadwick Boseman and the rise of colon cancer in young adults
item.description: Colorectal cancer is the second-leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States. Boseman’s case illustrates the importance of more screening—and addressing systemic inequities in health care.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Inside the derecho that pummeled the Midwest
item.description: On August 10, a weather complex known as a “derecho” sent intense winds and thunderstorms over a 700-mile stretch from Nebraska to Indiana. Now, Iowa works to recover from its damage.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Dwarf planet Ceres has salty water and appears geologically active
item.description: High-resolution images from NASA’s Dawn Orbiter suggest our solar system’s largest asteroid may have an ancient underground ocean, but some scientists are skeptical.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: The 2020 Perseid meteor shower peaks tonight
item.description: Here’s how to watch and what you’ll see.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Explore At-Home Agriculture with NOVA Education
item.description: Join NOVA Education for our "Backyard Farm to Table" virtual field trip series about at-home agriculture.

item.title: PBS series NOVA nominated for three 2020 Emmy Awards
item.description: The network tops the list with 48 nominations.
item.dc:creator: Dante Graves

item.title: NASA’s Perseverance Mars rover and first-ever space helicopter launch Thursday
item.description: The Mars 2020 mission will begin with July 30th’s launch from Cape Canaveral, Florida, at 7:50 a.m. EDT.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: What polio in post-WWII America can teach us about living in a pandemic
item.description: My grandmother’s 1946 ‘polio summer’ featured quarantines, canceled events, and remote learning. Her story is a reminder that we’ve been here before.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: How the stress of racism can harm your health—and what that has to do with Covid-19
item.description: ‘Allostatic load’ explains how chronic stress can cause wear and tear on the body, increasing your risk of hypertension, depression, diabetes, and more.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Interview: A disease modeler talks Covid-19, contact tracing, and quarantine
item.description: Rae Wannier is trying to understand the effects of shelter-in-place orders—while sheltering in place.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Interview: Tropical paleontology and being #BlackInNature
item.description: Paleobiologist Melissa Kemp says humans have been introducing species to the Caribbean since long before Columbus arrived—and she’s helping piece that history together.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: The unlikely journey of an eagle feather
item.description: When an eagle dies in America, it may end up at one of our eagle repositories—unique institutions working to protect both birds of prey and Native American traditions.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Covid-19 patients sharing ventilators is possible—but not ideal
item.description: The science of coventilation for coronavirus cases illustrates a complicated dilemma.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Greenberg

item.title: Bring Climate Science to the Digital Classroom with the Polar Lab
item.description: Online, interactive resources for teaching climate science and climate change to middle and high school students

item.title: Five Technology Documentaries Streaming Right Now
item.description: Five episodes exploring the revolution and ethics of technology.
item.dc:creator: NOVA STAFF

item.title: Meet the NOVA Science Studio Team
item.dc:creator: Tenijah Hamilton

item.title: NOVA Marathons: Health & Medicine
item.description: Six episodes exploring the fascinating science and innovations in health and medicine.
item.dc:creator: NOVA STAFF

item.title: Scientists find warm water beneath Antarctica’s most at-risk glacier
item.description: Thwaites Glacier is melting fast. But to understand how climate change is driving its decline, scientists need to send instruments through 2,000 feet of ice into the water below.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: Take a Virtual Field Trip with NOVA Education
item.description: Join NOVA on three virtual field trips this month in celebration of Earth Day and Environmental Education Month.

item.title: NOVA Marathons: Animals
item.description: Five episodes exploring the companionship, communication, and amazingness of animals.
item.dc:creator: NOVA STAFF

item.title: NOVA Marathons: Planet Earth
item.description: Six episodes exploring our unique and awe-inspiring planet.
item.dc:creator: NOVA STAFF

item.title: NOVA Marathons: Space & The Universe
item.description: Six episodes exploring the vast, mysterious, and powerful universe we live in.
item.dc:creator: NOVA STAFF

item.title: NOVA Resources for At-Home Learning
Experiencing Extremes: Plunging into Polar Pasts with NOVA to Reveal Future Climates
item.description: NOVA Labs Intern Chloe Nosan reflects on her experience working on the platform's newest resource on global climate change: The Polar Lab.

item.title: The 10 most popular NOVA stories of 2019
item.description: We’ve counted down our ten most-read articles of 2019 and found that health and medicine, physics—and of course animals—were fan-favorite topics this year.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: How “brown fat” helps you cope with cold weather
item.description: Shivering can activate a series of “heating stations” for your blood vessels—but they take a little while to get up and running.
item.dc:creator: Hanna Ali

item.title: The top 10 science stories of 2019
item.description: Black holes, gene editing, and quantum computing wowed us—while new climate findings and racial bias in medicine brought renewed urgency.
item.dc:creator: Sukee Bennett

item.title: What’s up with Jupiter’s wandering magnetic field?
item.description: In 2018 and 2019, data from NASA’s Juno mission revealed new discoveries about Jupiter’s bizarre magnetic field.
item.dc:creator: Diego Arenas

item.title: Communities come face-to-face with the growing power of facial recognition technology
item.description: As law enforcement agencies deploy AI-powered facial recognition systems, some communities are pushing back, insisting on having a say in how they’re used.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Snow

item.title: Like Neanderthals, early modern humans used their teeth as tools
item.description: New findings bolster the argument that the two groups of early humans had a lot of behavioral similarities.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Dogs, drones, and DNA: How eight “extinct” species were rediscovered
item.description: A giant tortoise, a seabird, and a gecko all went undetected by scientists for more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Flaherty

item.title: How polar bear guards protect the largest Arctic expedition ever
item.description: A glimpse into the lives of the MOSAiC mission’s polar bear guards—and the powerful predators they watch for.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: How mechanical engineering could revolutionize the study of preterm birth
item.description: Scientists are using artificial cervices and 3D models of the uterus to better understand pregnancy and childbirth.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Anatomy professor uses 500-year-old da Vinci drawings to guide cadaver dissection
item.description: Leonardo da Vinci dissected some 30 cadavers in his lifetime, leaving behind a trove of beautiful—and accurate—anatomical drawings.
item.dc:creator: Shantal Riley

item.title: Feast your eyes on the first-ever photos of a silver-backed chevrotain in the wild
item.description: The images confirm the species, which has been “lost” to science for 29 years, is alive and well in its native Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: In a controversial study, DNA from today’s southern Africans hints at possible “homeland” for modern humans
item.description: But many questions remain about the true origin of the Homo sapiens species.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: From ashes to AI: How technology puts a new lens on ancient texts
item.description: Recent breakthroughs in scanning, image processing, and machine learning are helping researchers read historic documents once considered lost to time.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Invasive, flammable grasses now blanket much of the United States
item.description: New research quantifies the fire risks of eight species of invasive grass.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Poor-quality sleep could prime the brain for an anxious day
item.description: From a neurobiology perspective, anxiety and sleep deprivation look very much alike.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: How measles virus triggers immune system ‘amnesia’
item.description: In addition to causing disease itself, the virus destroys immune cells trained to respond to other pathogens the body has encountered before.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Vampire bats form lasting bonds of ‘friendship,’ just like us
item.description: The relationships these winged mammals forge in captivity are strong enough to survive the jarring transition back into the wild.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: New study more than triples estimates of people at risk from rising seas
item.description: Researchers used artificial intelligence to reevaluate elevations vulnerable to rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Racially-biased medical algorithm prioritizes white patients over black patients
item.description: The algorithm was based on the faulty assumption that health care spending is a good proxy for wellbeing. But there seems to be a quick fix.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: New fossils capture million-year timeline of life after the dinosaurs died
item.description: Thousands of fossils from Colorado show how plants and animals evolved together after an asteroid devastated life on Earth.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Google says it just achieved “quantum supremacy.” Is it true?
item.description: If validated, Google’s new technology may bring us closer to a future of ultra-efficient computing.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: What caused Saturn’s strange spell of storms in 2018?
item.description: Researchers have uncovered a new category of giant storm on Saturn’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: World’s loudest bird flirts by screaming in your face
item.description: Researchers aren’t sure how these birds maintain this deafening mating ritual without damaging their hearing.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: These 480-million-year-old conga lines preserve early signs of group behavior
item.description: Nearly half a billion years ago, marine arthropods called trilobites lined up single-file before meeting a tragic end.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: World’s fastest-running ant scuttles over scalding Saharan sands at super speeds
item.description: Saharan silver ants don’t have the longest limbs. But they make up for it with a sprightly combination of fast pacing, light-footedness, and synchronized stepping that effectively turns their six legs into two.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Lab-grown mini-brains highlight developmental differences between humans and great apes
item.description: In a new study, brain-like organoids made from human cells were slower to mature than their chimpanzee and macaque counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Scientists retract study linking CRISPR baby mutation to early death
item.description: The study, originally published in June, contained an error that its authors caught months later.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: To predict the next infectious disease outbreak, ask a computer
item.description: Mathematical modeling and AI can pick out patterns preceding epidemics that human brains can’t readily discern.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Meet the second confirmed interstellar object to enter our solar system
item.description: The comet, 2I/Borisov, comes from another planetary system, but bears a remarkable resemblance to local space rocks.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Refrigerators of the future may be inspired by the weird physics of rubber
item.description: A new refrigeration technique harnesses the ability of rubber and other materials to cool down when released from a tight twist.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: October Events: "Look Who's Driving" Screenings & Panel Discussions
item.description: This month, NOVA is hosting three events that will dive into how autonomous vehicles work, how they may change the way we live, and whether we will ever be able to entrust them with our lives.

item.title: Saturn unseats Jupiter as planet with the most moons in our solar system
item.description: Astronomers discovered 20 new moons around Saturn, bringing its total to 82.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Salts in Gale Crater suggest Mars lost its water through drastic climate fluctuations
item.description: New data from NASA’s Curiosity rover suggests that water vacated Mars in fits and starts.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Scientists may now be able to predict forest die-off up to 19 months in advance
item.description: Even forests that look green from space can show symptoms of impending decline.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Scientists just snapped the best image yet of the universe’s ‘cosmic web’
item.description: Light from nearby galaxies illuminated the web’s ‘threads,’ making them directly visible to telescopes on Earth.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Wildlife trade may put nearly 9,000 land-based species at risk of extinction
item.description: A new analysis predicts that 3,196 animals will join the 5,579 already snared in the global wildlife market.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Planet Nine probably isn’t a black hole. But it might be worth checking
item.description: A pair of physicists think it’s possible that a tiny black hole left over from the universe’s early days lurks in the outer solar system.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Rabbit study hints at the origins of the female orgasm
item.description: Researchers used rabbits and antidepressants to search for a link between orgasm and ovulation in female mammals.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Cooking changed human history. Did it change our microbes too?
item.description: Gut microbes react differently to raw and cooked versions of the same foods.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Study finds kittens bond with their human caregivers like babies do
item.description: They’re not as aloof as some think.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: To save climate-sensitive pikas, conservation efforts need to get local
item.description: American pikas’ responses to climate are driven by location, location, location.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria in farm animals are rising in low- and middle-income countries
item.description: That spells trouble for the entire planet.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: An ancient asteroid collision fostered life on Earth
item.description: A new study suggests a plume of dust once blocked the sun’s rays from Earth, triggering an ice age some 466 million years ago.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Scientists are about to lock themselves into an Arctic ice floe for a year
item.description: In the largest Arctic expedition yet, researchers will gather as much data as they can on the fading ice—and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Soot from polluted air can reach the fetal side of the placenta
item.description: A new study hints at the ways in which air pollution may directly impact a fetus.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Astronomers may have just detected the most massive neutron star yet
item.description: It’s almost too dense to exist. Almost.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Astronomers discover two giant, high-energy ‘bubbles’ at the center of the Milky Way
item.description: The gargantuan structures hint at a massive explosion in our galaxy’s past.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Popular pesticide throws off birds’ feeding and migration schedules
item.description: Delays during migration can imperil birds’ chances of a successful breeding season.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Water vapor found on an ‘Earth-sized’ exoplanet 110 light-years from home
item.description: Scientists say the planet, called K2-18b, is “the best candidate for habitability” beyond our solar system.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Intricate ‘toe maps’ exist in the brains of artists who paint with their feet
item.description: Two men born without arms showcase the brain’s extraordinary flexibility.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Newly described species of electric eel serves up shocks of 860 volts
item.description: That earns this fish, Electrophorus voltai, the title of the strongest known living source of electricity.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: Supercooling preserves donor livers for more than a day
item.description: The breakthrough could mean that fewer organs go to waste before they make it into a transplant recipient.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: How K?lauea’s lava birthed an algal bloom visible from space
item.description: Lava descending into Hawai‘i’s ocean drove an upward surge of deep sea nutrients, cultivating life at the surface.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
